stem: A 21-year-old client with bulimia nervosa presents with sudden, sharp chest pain after an episode of self-induced vomiting. Based on the documentation in the Serial GI & Metabolic Surveillance Log, which condition is the most likely cause of the client's current status?

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing Boerhaave Syndrome (a1), a full-thickness rupture of the esophagus due to the pressure of forceful vomiting. Key findings include pneumomediastinum (air escaping into the chest), subcutaneous emphysema (crepitus in the neck), and pleural fluid positive for salivary amylase (spit leaking into the chest). The client's shock (BP 82/48) and fever (102.4°F) indicate mediastinitis. This condition is a surgical emergency with high mortality if untreated, unlike a Mallory-Weiss tear (a2), which is a mucosal laceration causing bleeding.
clinicalPearls: Macler's Triad for Boerhaave Syndrome: Vomiting, Chest Pain, Subcutaneous Emphysema.
A crunching sound heard with the heartbeat (Hamman's Crunch) indicates pneumomediastinum.
Management of Boerhaave Syndrome is similar to major trauma: NPO, IV antibiotics, and emergent surgical intervention.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting Mallory-Weiss tear (a2) because it is a more commonly recognized complication of eating disorders.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the presence of air. If air is detected in the neck (crepitus) or chest (pneumomediastinum), suspect a full-thickness esophageal rupture (Boerhaave Syndrome). Mallory-Weiss tear involves only a superficial mucosal laceration and bleeding.

exhibits.title: SBAR Situation
exhibits.content:
Situation: Acute chest pain following purging episode.
Background: History of bulimia (8 years). Frequent purging (4-6x/day).
Assessment: Client is in severe distress. Crepitus (crunching sound) felt on palpation of the neck and chest wall.
Recommendation: Stat Chest X-ray.

exhibits.title: Imaging Results
exhibits.content:
Chest X-ray (Static): Pneumomediastinum (air in the mediastinum). Left-sided pleural effusion. No pulmonary nodules.
CT Chest with Contrast: Extravasation of oral contrast into the pleural space.

exhibits.title: Vital Signs & Labs
exhibits.content: BP 82/48, HR 142, T 102.4°F. WBC 22,000. Pleural fluid analysis: Positive for salivary amylase.
